title: PersistentVolumeClaim (PVC)
task: The MariaDB Deployment in the mariadb namespace has been accidentally deleted. Please restore the Deployment and ensure data persistence. Follow these steps:
environment:
- Cluster: 2-node Kubernetes v1.28.15 (master01 + worker01)
- Master node: ec2-34-201-252-187.compute-1.amazonaws.com (34.201.252.187, Private: 172.31.80.10)
- Worker node: ec2-54-144-18-63.compute-1.amazonaws.com (54.144.18.63, Private: 172.31.80.11)
- Container runtime: containerd
- CNI: Flannel
preparation:
# 1) Storage class and namespace already exist
kubectl get storageclass  # local-path available
kubectl get ns mariadb    # namespace exists

# 2) PersistentVolume already exists
kubectl get pv mariadb-pv  # 250Mi, RWO, local-path

# 3) MariaDB Deployment template available at ~/mariadb-deployment.yaml
# Note: MariaDB image will be pulled from Docker Hub automatically
steps:
# 1) Connect to master node (exam will specify which node to use)
[candidate@base ~]$ ssh ubuntu@ec2-34-201-252-187.compute-1.amazonaws.com
[ubuntu@ec2-34-201-252-187.compute-1.amazonaws.com ~]$

# 2) Verify environment and existing resources
[ubuntu@ec2-34-201-252-187.compute-1.amazonaws.com ~]$ kubectl get nodes
NAME              STATUS   ROLES           AGE   VERSION
ec2-34-201-252-187.compute-1.amazonaws.com   Ready    control-plane   15m   v1.28.15
ec2-54-144-18-63.compute-1.amazonaws.com   Ready    <none>          12m   v1.28.15

[ubuntu@ec2-34-201-252-187.compute-1.amazonaws.com ~]$ kubectl get pv
NAME         CAPACITY   ACCESS MODES   RECLAIM POLICY   STATUS      CLAIM   STORAGECLASS   REASON   AGE
mariadb-pv   250Mi      RWO            Retain           Available           local-path              5m

[ubuntu@ec2-34-201-252-187.compute-1.amazonaws.com ~]$ kubectl get storageclass
NAME         PROVISIONER                    RECLAIMPOLICY   VOLUMEBINDINGMODE      ALLOWVOLUMEEXPANSION   AGE
local-path   kubernetes.io/no-provisioner   Delete          WaitForFirstConsumer   false                  5m

# 3) Create PVC (use vim or nano - exam allows both)
[ubuntu@ec2-34-201-252-187.compute-1.amazonaws.com ~]$ vim pvc.yaml

# Press 'i' to enter insert mode, then paste:
apiVersion: v1
kind: PersistentVolumeClaim
metadata:
  name: mariadb
  namespace: mariadb
spec:
  storageClassName: local-path
  accessModes:
    - ReadWriteOnce
  resources:
    requests:
      storage: 250Mi

# Press Esc, then :wq to save and exit

# Apply the PVC
[ubuntu@ec2-34-201-252-187.compute-1.amazonaws.com ~]$ kubectl apply -f pvc.yaml
persistentvolumeclaim/mariadb created

# Verify PVC creation (will be Pending until pod is scheduled)
[ubuntu@ec2-34-201-252-187.compute-1.amazonaws.com ~]$ kubectl get pvc -n mariadb
NAME      STATUS    VOLUME   CAPACITY   ACCESS MODES   STORAGECLASS   AGE
mariadb   Pending                                      local-path     5s

# 4) Edit the existing MariaDB Deployment file
[ubuntu@ec2-34-201-252-187.compute-1.amazonaws.com ~]$ vim ~/mariadb-deployment.yaml

# The file already exists with basic deployment. Add volumes and volumeMounts:
# Navigate to the containers section and add volumeMounts after ports:
        volumeMounts:
        - name: mariadb-data
          mountPath: /var/lib/mysql

# Navigate to the end of spec section and add volumes before the last closing brace:
      volumes:
      - name: mariadb-data
        persistentVolumeClaim:
          claimName: mariadb

# Complete file should look like:
apiVersion: apps/v1
kind: Deployment
metadata:
  name: mariadb
  namespace: mariadb
spec:
  replicas: 1
  selector:
    matchLabels:
      app: mariadb
  template:
    metadata:
      labels:
        app: mariadb
    spec:
      containers:
      - name: mariadb
        image: mariadb:10.5
        imagePullPolicy: IfNotPresent
        ports:
        - containerPort: 3306
        volumeMounts:
        - name: mariadb-data
          mountPath: /var/lib/mysql
        env:
        - name: MYSQL_ROOT_PASSWORD
          value: "rootpassword"
      volumes:
      - name: mariadb-data
        persistentVolumeClaim:
          claimName: mariadb

# Save and exit (:wq)

# 5) Apply the updated Deployment
[ubuntu@ec2-34-201-252-187.compute-1.amazonaws.com ~]$ kubectl apply -f ~/mariadb-deployment.yaml
deployment.apps/mariadb created

# 6) Verify deployment is running and stable
[ubuntu@ec2-34-201-252-187.compute-1.amazonaws.com ~]$ kubectl get deployment -n mariadb
NAME      READY   UP-TO-DATE   AVAILABLE   AGE
mariadb   1/1     1            1           30s

[ubuntu@ec2-34-201-252-187.compute-1.amazonaws.com ~]$ kubectl get pods -n mariadb
NAME                       READY   STATUS    RESTARTS   AGE
mariadb-6789d69fc8-xxxxx   1/1     Running   0          35s

# Verify PVC is now bound
[ubuntu@ec2-34-201-252-187.compute-1.amazonaws.com ~]$ kubectl get pvc -n mariadb
NAME      STATUS   VOLUME       CAPACITY   ACCESS MODES   STORAGECLASS   AGE
mariadb   Bound    mariadb-pv   250Mi      RWO            local-path     2m

# 7) Optional: Test database functionality (if time permits)
[ubuntu@ec2-34-201-252-187.compute-1.amazonaws.com ~]$ kubectl exec -n mariadb deployment/mariadb -- mysql -uroot -prootpassword -e "SELECT VERSION();"
VERSION()
10.5.29-MariaDB-ubu2004

# 8) Exit back to base node (if exam requires)
[ubuntu@ec2-34-201-252-187.compute-1.amazonaws.com ~]$ exit
[candidate@base ~]$

# Task completed successfully:
# âœ… PVC created with correct specifications (mariadb, 250Mi, RWO)
# âœ… PVC bound to existing PV (mariadb-pv)
# âœ… MariaDB Deployment updated with persistent volume
# âœ… Deployment running and stable (1/1 Ready)
# âœ… Database functional and data will persist across pod restarts

tips:
ğŸ¯ CRITICAL EXAM CONCEPTS:

1. PV/PVC BINDING PROCESS:
   â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”    â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”    â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”
   â”‚PV Available â”‚ -> â”‚PVC Pending  â”‚ -> â”‚PVC Bound    â”‚
   â”‚(no claim)   â”‚    â”‚(no pod yet) â”‚    â”‚(pod created)â”‚
   â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜    â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜    â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜

2. VOLUME BINDING MODES:
   â€¢ Immediate: PVC binds to PV immediately
   â€¢ WaitForFirstConsumer: PVC waits until pod is scheduled

3. ACCESS MODES (CRITICAL FOR EXAM):
   â€¢ RWO (ReadWriteOnce): Single node read/write
   â€¢ ROX (ReadOnlyMany): Multiple nodes read-only  
   â€¢ RWX (ReadWriteMany): Multiple nodes read/write

ğŸš€ EXAM SUCCESS STRATEGIES:

1. TIME MANAGEMENT:
   â€¢ This question: 8-12 minutes maximum
   â€¢ Always verify with kubectl get commands
   â€¢ Use kubectl apply -f instead of create

2. COMMON MISTAKES TO AVOID:
   âŒ Wrong namespace specification
   âŒ Mismatched storage class names
   âŒ Incorrect volumeMount path
   âŒ Missing PVC claimName in deployment

3. VERIFICATION CHECKLIST:
   âœ… kubectl get pv (check STATUS: Available -> Bound)
   âœ… kubectl get pvc -n mariadb (check STATUS: Pending -> Bound)
   âœ… kubectl get pods -n mariadb (check STATUS: Running)
   âœ… kubectl get deployment -n mariadb (check READY: 1/1)

4. KUBECTL SHORTCUTS (SAVE TIME):
   â€¢ k = kubectl (if alias configured)
   â€¢ kubectl get pv,pvc -A (check all at once)
   â€¢ kubectl describe pvc mariadb -n mariadb (troubleshoot binding)

ğŸ“š STORAGE DOMAIN KNOWLEDGE (10% of CKA):

â€¢ PersistentVolume: Cluster-wide storage resource
â€¢ PersistentVolumeClaim: Namespace-scoped storage request
â€¢ StorageClass: Defines storage provisioning policy
â€¢ Volume Types: hostPath, NFS, cloud storage (EBS, etc.)
â€¢ Reclaim Policies: Retain, Delete, Recycle

ğŸ”§ TROUBLESHOOTING TIPS:

PVC Stuck in Pending?
â†’ Check: StorageClass exists, PV available, access modes match

Pod Stuck in Pending?
â†’ Check: PVC bound, node has resources, scheduling constraints

Mount Issues?
â†’ Check: volumeMount path, PVC claimName, container permissions

task:
Task:
Migrate an existing web application from Ingress to Gateway API. You must maintain HTTPS access.
environment:
- Cluster: 2-node Kubernetes v1.28.15 (master01 + worker01)
- Master node: ec2-34-201-252-187.compute-1.amazonaws.com (34.201.252.187, Private: 172.31.80.10)
- Worker node: ec2-54-144-18-63.compute-1.amazonaws.com (54.144.18.63, Private: 172.31.80.11)
- Container runtime: containerd
- CNI: Calico + Flannel
preparation:
# 1) Web application already deployed
kubectl get deployment,service web  # web app running

# 2) TLS certificate and secret already created
kubectl get secret web-cert  # TLS secret available

# 3) Gateway API CRDs already installed
kubectl get crd | grep gateway  # Gateway API resources available

# 4) Existing Ingress resource ready for migration
kubectl get ingress web  # Ingress with HTTPS and routing configuration

# 5) nginx GatewayClass available
kubectl get gatewayclass nginx  # GatewayClass ready for use
steps:
# 1) Connect to master node (exam will specify which node to use)
[candidate@base ~]$ ssh ubuntu@ec2-34-201-252-187.compute-1.amazonaws.com
[ubuntu@ec2-34-201-252-187.compute-1.amazonaws.com ~]$

# 2) Examine existing Ingress resource to understand current configuration
[ubuntu@ec2-34-201-252-187.compute-1.amazonaws.com ~]$ kubectl get ingress web -o yaml
apiVersion: networking.k8s.io/v1
kind: Ingress
metadata:
  name: web
  namespace: default
spec:
  ingressClassName: nginx
  rules:
  - host: gateway.web.k8s.local
    http:
      paths:
      - backend:
          service:
            name: web
            port:
              number: 80
        path: /
        pathType: Prefix
  tls:
  - hosts:
    - gateway.web.k8s.local
    secretName: web-cert

# Key information extracted:
# - Hostname: gateway.web.k8s.local
# - TLS secret: web-cert
# - Backend service: web (port 80)
# - Path: / (PathPrefix)
# - IngressClass: nginx

# 3) Verify GatewayClass is available
[ubuntu@ec2-34-201-252-187.compute-1.amazonaws.com ~]$ kubectl get gatewayclass
NAME    CONTROLLER                           ACCEPTED   AGE
nginx   nginx.org/nginx-gateway-controller   Unknown    5m

# 4) Create Gateway resource
[ubuntu@ec2-34-201-252-187.compute-1.amazonaws.com ~]$ vim gateway.yaml

# Press 'i' to enter insert mode, then create:
apiVersion: gateway.networking.k8s.io/v1
kind: Gateway
metadata:
  name: web-local-gateway
spec:
  gatewayClassName: nginx
  listeners:
  - name: https
    protocol: HTTPS
    port: 443
    hostname: gateway.web.k8s.local
    tls:
      mode: Terminate
      certificateRefs:
      - name: web-cert

# Press Esc, then :wq to save and exit

# 5) Apply the Gateway
[ubuntu@ec2-34-201-252-187.compute-1.amazonaws.com ~]$ kubectl apply -f gateway.yaml
gateway.gateway.networking.k8s.io/web-local-gateway created

# 6) Verify Gateway creation
[ubuntu@ec2-34-201-252-187.compute-1.amazonaws.com ~]$ kubectl get gateway web-local-gateway
NAME                CLASS   ADDRESS   PROGRAMMED   AGE
web-local-gateway   nginx             Unknown      10s

# Note: PROGRAMMED status may show "Unknown" in simulation environment
# In real exam with proper Gateway controller, it should show "True"

# 7) Create HTTPRoute resource
[ubuntu@ec2-34-201-252-187.compute-1.amazonaws.com ~]$ vim httproute.yaml

# Press 'i' to enter insert mode, then create:
apiVersion: gateway.networking.k8s.io/v1
kind: HTTPRoute
metadata:
  name: web-route
spec:
  parentRefs:
  - name: web-local-gateway
  hostnames:
  - "gateway.web.k8s.local"
  rules:
  - matches:
    - path:
        type: PathPrefix
        value: /
    backendRefs:
    - name: web
      port: 80

# Press Esc, then :wq to save and exit

# 8) Apply the HTTPRoute
[ubuntu@ec2-34-201-252-187.compute-1.amazonaws.com ~]$ kubectl apply -f httproute.yaml
httproute.gateway.networking.k8s.io/web-route created

# 9) Verify HTTPRoute creation
[ubuntu@ec2-34-201-252-187.compute-1.amazonaws.com ~]$ kubectl get httproute web-route
NAME        HOSTNAMES                   AGE
web-route   ["gateway.web.k8s.local"]   15s

# 10) Test Gateway API configuration (if controller is available)
[ubuntu@ec2-34-201-252-187.compute-1.amazonaws.com ~]$ curl -Lk https://gateway.web.k8s.local:31443
# Note: This test may not work in simulation environment without proper Gateway controller
# In real exam, this should return the nginx welcome page

# 11) Delete the existing Ingress resource
[ubuntu@ec2-34-201-252-187.compute-1.amazonaws.com ~]$ kubectl delete ingress web
ingress.networking.k8s.io "web" deleted

# 12) Verify Ingress deletion
[ubuntu@ec2-34-201-252-187.compute-1.amazonaws.com ~]$ kubectl get ingress
No resources found in default namespace.

# 13) Final verification of Gateway API migration
[ubuntu@ec2-34-201-252-187.compute-1.amazonaws.com ~]$ kubectl get gateway,httproute
NAME                                                  CLASS   ADDRESS   PROGRAMMED   AGE
gateway.gateway.networking.k8s.io/web-local-gateway   nginx             Unknown      2m

NAME                                            HOSTNAMES                   AGE
httproute.gateway.networking.k8s.io/web-route   ["gateway.web.k8s.local"]   90s

# 14) Verify backend service is still available
[ubuntu@ec2-34-201-252-187.compute-1.amazonaws.com ~]$ kubectl get service web
NAME   TYPE        CLUSTER-IP       EXTERNAL-IP   PORT(S)   AGE
web    ClusterIP   10.103.107.208   <none>        80/TCP    10m

# 15) Check Gateway and HTTPRoute status (optional)
[ubuntu@ec2-34-201-252-187.compute-1.amazonaws.com ~]$ kubectl describe gateway web-local-gateway
Name:         web-local-gateway
Namespace:    default
Labels:       <none>
Annotations:  <none>
API Version:  gateway.networking.k8s.io/v1
Kind:         Gateway
Spec:
  Gateway Class Name:  nginx
  Listeners:
    Hostname:  gateway.web.k8s.local
    Name:      https
    Port:      443
    Protocol:  HTTPS
    Tls:
      Certificate Refs:
        Name:  web-cert
      Mode:    Terminate

[ubuntu@ec2-34-201-252-187.compute-1.amazonaws.com ~]$ kubectl describe httproute web-route
Name:         web-route
Namespace:    default
Labels:       <none>
Annotations:  <none>
API Version:  gateway.networking.k8s.io/v1
Kind:         HTTPRoute
Spec:
  Hostnames:
    gateway.web.k8s.local
  Parent Refs:
    Name:  web-local-gateway
  Rules:
    Backend Refs:
      Name:  web
      Port:  80
    Matches:
      Path:
        Type:   PathPrefix
        Value:  /

# 16) Exit back to base node (if exam requires)
[ubuntu@ec2-34-201-252-187.compute-1.amazonaws.com ~]$ exit
[candidate@base ~]$

title: Sidecar Container
task: To integrate traditional applications into Kubernetes' logging architecture (such as kubectl logs), the common practice is to add a sidecar container for log streaming.
preparation:
# 1) Create deployment resource
# Import busybox stable image on worker node
root@worker-node:~# ctr -n=k8s.io images import busybox_stable.tar

cat <<EOF | kubectl apply -f -
apiVersion: apps/v1
kind: Deployment
metadata:
  name: sync-leverager
  labels:
    app: sync-leverager
spec:
  replicas: 1
  selector:
    matchLabels:
      app: sync-leverager
  template:
    metadata:
      labels:
        app: sync-leverager
    spec:
      containers:
      - name: sync-leverager
        image: nginx:1.25
        imagePullPolicy: IfNotPresent
        command: ["/bin/sh", "-c", "while true; do echo \"$(date) INFO log line\" >> /var/log/sync-leverager.log; sleep 5; done"]

[candidate@cka000012~]$

# Note: In simulation environment, work directly from candidate@base:~$ terminal
# In real exam, SSH to the specified node as required

# 2) Export the existing deployment to YAML file
[candidate@cka000012 ~]$ kubectl get deployment sync-leverager -o yaml > sidecar.yaml

# 3) Edit the YAML file
[candidate@cka000012 ~]$ vim sidecar.yaml

# Note: Use :set paste before pressing i to insert to prevent formatting issues
# The following is the modified YAML (insertion position and indentation adjusted according to actual exam requirements)

# Complete YAML should look like this:
apiVersion: apps/v1
kind: Deployment
metadata:
  name: sync-leverager
  labels:
    app: sync-leverager
spec:
  replicas: 1
  selector:
    matchLabels:
      app: sync-leverager
  template:
    metadata:
      labels:
        app: sync-leverager
    spec:
      volumes:  # Add this section
      - name: varlog
        emptyDir: {}
      containers:
      - name: sync-leverager
        image: nginx:1.25
        command: ["/bin/sh", "-c", "while true; do echo \"$(date) INFO log line\" >> /var/log/sync-leverager.log; sleep 5; done"]
        volumeMounts:  # Add this section to existing container
        - name: varlog
          mountPath: /var/log
      - name: sidecar  # Add this entire sidecar container
        image: busybox:stable
        imagePullPolicy: IfNotPresent
        args: ["/bin/sh", "-c", "tail -n+1 -f /var/log/sync-leverager.log"]
        volumeMounts:
        - name: varlog
          mountPath: /var/log

# Key modifications:
# 1. Add volumes section with emptyDir volume named "varlog"
# 2. Add volumeMounts to existing sync-leverager container
# 3. Add new sidecar container with specified image and command
# 4. Add volumeMounts to sidecar container

# Apply the modified deployment
[candidate@cka000012 ~]$ kubectl apply -f sidecar.yaml

# 4) Check deployment status
[candidate@cka000012 ~]$ kubectl get deployment sync-leverager

# Sun Mar 23 05:15:32 UTC 2025 INFO log line
# Sun Mar 23 05:15:37 UTC 2025 INFO log line
# Sun Mar 23 05:15:42 UTC 2025 INFO log line

# Verify both containers are present
[candidate@cka000012 ~]$ kubectl get pod <pod-name> -o jsonpath='{.spec.containers[*].name}'

# Expected output:

[candidate@cka000016 ~]$ sudo systemctl enable cri-docker

# Expected output:

[candidate@cka000016 ~]$ sudo systemctl start cri-docker

# Verify the service is running
[candidate@cka000016 ~]$ sudo systemctl status cri-docker

# Expected output should show "active (running)"

# 4) Configure system parameters (must ensure they persist after reboot)
# Load the br_netfilter module
[candidate@cka000016 ~]$ sudo modprobe br_netfilter

# Make the module load automatically on boot
[candidate@cka000016 ~]$ echo 'br_netfilter' | sudo tee /etc/modules-load.d/k8s.conf

# Edit /etc/sysctl.conf to add kernel parameters
[candidate@cka000016 ~]$ sudo vim /etc/sysctl.conf

# In vim, execute the following:
# :set paste
# Press i to enter insert mode
# Add the following content to the end of the file:

# Kubernetes required kernel parameters
net.bridge.bridge-nf-call-iptables = 1
net.ipv6.conf.all.forwarding = 1
net.ipv4.ip_forward = 1
net.netfilter.nf_conntrack_max = 131072

# Save and exit: type :wq

[candidate@cka000016 ~]$ sudo sysctl -p

# Expected output:
# net.bridge.bridge-nf-call-iptables = 1
# net.ipv6.conf.all.forwarding = 1
# net.ipv4.ip_forward = 1

[candidate@cka000016 ~]$ sudo sysctl net.ipv6.conf.all.forwarding
[candidate@cka000016 ~]$ sudo sysctl net.ipv4.ip_forward
[candidate@cka000016 ~]$ sudo sysctl net.netfilter.nf_conntrack_max

# All should return the values set above (1, 1, 1, 131072 respectively)

# 7) Additional verification commands

[candidate@cka000016 ~]$ sudo systemctl status cri-docker.socket

# Verify Docker is running
[candidate@cka000016 ~]$ sudo systemctl status docker

# Test cri-dockerd connectivity
[candidate@cka000016 ~]$ sudo cri-dockerd --version

# Check if the br_netfilter module is loaded
[candidate@cka000016 ~]$ lsmod | grep br_netfilter

# 8) Alternative method for persistent sysctl configuration
# Instead of editing /etc/sysctl.conf, you can create a dedicated file:
# sudo vim /etc/sysctl.d/99-kubernetes-cri.conf
# Add the same parameters there

# 9) Troubleshooting commands (if needed)
# Check system logs for cri-dockerd
[candidate@cka000016 ~]$ sudo journalctl -u cri-docker -f

# Check if all required services are enabled
[candidate@cka000016 ~]$ sudo systemctl is-enabled docker cri-docker

# Verify network bridge functionality
[candidate@cka000016 ~]$ sudo iptables -L

# 10) Exit current node and return to base node (in real exam)
[candidate@cka000016~]$ exit
[candidate@base~]$

# Important Notes:
# - cri-dockerd acts as a bridge between Docker and Kubernetes CRI
# - System parameters must persist across reboots for production use
# - The br_netfilter module is essential for Kubernetes networking
# - All services should be enabled to start automatically on boot

[candidate@base ~]$ ssh ubuntu@ec2-34-201-252-187.compute-1.amazonaws.com
[ubuntu@ec2-34-201-252-187.compute-1.amazonaws.com ~]$

# 2) Verify existing resources and check IngressClass
[ubuntu@ec2-34-201-252-187.compute-1.amazonaws.com ~]$ kubectl get deployment -n sound echoserver
NAME         READY   UP-TO-DATE   AVAILABLE   AGE
echoserver   1/1     1            1           5m

[ubuntu@ec2-34-201-252-187.compute-1.amazonaws.com ~]$ kubectl get svc -n sound echoserver-service
NAME                 TYPE        CLUSTER-IP     EXTERNAL-IP   PORT(S)    AGE
echoserver-service   ClusterIP   10.98.192.75   <none>        8080/TCP   5m

[ubuntu@ec2-34-201-252-187.compute-1.amazonaws.com ~]$ kubectl get ingressclasses.networking.k8s.io
NAME    CONTROLLER             PARAMETERS   AGE
nginx   k8s.io/ingress-nginx   <none>       10m

# 3) Create Ingress resource
[ubuntu@ec2-34-201-252-187.compute-1.amazonaws.com ~]$ vim ingress.yaml

# Press 'i' to enter insert mode, then create:
apiVersion: networking.k8s.io/v1
kind: Ingress
metadata:
  name: echo-hello
  namespace: sound
  annotations:
    nginx.ingress.kubernetes.io/rewrite-target: /
spec:
  ingressClassName: nginx
  rules:
  - host: example.org
    http:
      paths:
      - path: /echo-hello
        pathType: Prefix
        backend:
          service:
            name: echoserver-service
            port:
              number: 8080

# Press Esc, then :wq to save and exit

# 4) Apply the Ingress resource
[ubuntu@ec2-34-201-252-187.compute-1.amazonaws.com ~]$ kubectl apply -f ingress.yaml
ingress.networking.k8s.io/echo-hello created

# 5) Verify Ingress creation
[ubuntu@ec2-34-201-252-187.compute-1.amazonaws.com ~]$ kubectl get ingress -n sound
NAME         CLASS   HOSTS         ADDRESS   PORTS   AGE
echo-hello   nginx   example.org             80      30s

# Check Ingress details
[ubuntu@ec2-34-201-252-187.compute-1.amazonaws.com ~]$ kubectl describe ingress echo-hello -n sound
Name:             echo-hello
Labels:           <none>
Namespace:        sound
Address:          
Ingress Class:    nginx
Default backend:  <default>
Rules:
  Host         Path  Backends
  ----         ----  --------
  example.org  
               /echo-hello   echoserver-service:8080 (10.244.1.9:8080)
Annotations:   nginx.ingress.kubernetes.io/rewrite-target: /
Events:
  Type    Reason  Age   From                      Message
  ----    ------  ----  ----                      -------
  Normal  Sync    30s   nginx-ingress-controller  Scheduled for sync

# 6) Test Ingress functionality
# Get Ingress controller NodePort
[ubuntu@ec2-34-201-252-187.compute-1.amazonaws.com ~]$ kubectl get svc ingress-nginx-controller -n ingress-nginx
NAME                       TYPE           CLUSTER-IP      EXTERNAL-IP   PORT(S)                      AGE
ingress-nginx-controller   LoadBalancer   10.97.190.138   <pending>     80:30143/TCP,443:32657/TCP   15m

# Test using NodePort with Host header (exam environment method)
[ubuntu@ec2-34-201-252-187.compute-1.amazonaws.com ~]$ curl -H "Host: example.org" http://localhost:30143/echo-hello
CLIENT VALUES:
client_address=10.244.1.8
command=GET
real path=/
query=nil
request_version=1.1
request_uri=http://example.org:8080/

SERVER VALUES:
server_version=nginx/1.10.0
...

# Alternative test method (if curl with Host header works)
[ubuntu@ec2-34-201-252-187.compute-1.amazonaws.com ~]$ curl http://example.org/echo-hello
# Note: This requires DNS resolution or /etc/hosts entry in real exam

# 7) Verify service is accessible directly (troubleshooting)
[ubuntu@ec2-34-201-252-187.compute-1.amazonaws.com ~]$ kubectl get endpoints -n sound echoserver-service
NAME                 ENDPOINTS         AGE
echoserver-service   10.244.1.9:8080   10m

# Test service directly
[ubuntu@ec2-34-201-252-187.compute-1.amazonaws.com ~]$ curl 10.98.192.75:8080
CLIENT VALUES:
client_address=10.244.0.0
command=GET
real path=/
...

# 8) Additional verification commands
# Check Ingress controller logs (if needed for troubleshooting)
[ubuntu@ec2-34-201-252-187.compute-1.amazonaws.com ~]$ kubectl logs -n ingress-nginx deployment/ingress-nginx-controller --tail=10

# Check all resources in sound namespace
[ubuntu@ec2-34-201-252-187.compute-1.amazonaws.com ~]$ kubectl get all -n sound
NAME                              READY   STATUS    RESTARTS   AGE
pod/echoserver-78c9c475c8-xxxxx   1/1     Running   0          15m

NAME                         TYPE        CLUSTER-IP     EXTERNAL-IP   PORT(S)    AGE
service/echoserver-service   ClusterIP   10.98.192.75   <none>        8080/TCP   15m

NAME                         READY   UP-TO-DATE   AVAILABLE   AGE
deployment.apps/echoserver   1/1     1            1           15m

NAME                                    DESIRED   CURRENT   READY   AGE
replicaset.apps/echoserver-78c9c475c8   1         1         1       15m

# 9) Exit back to base node (if exam requires)
[ubuntu@ec2-34-201-252-187.compute-1.amazonaws.com ~]$ exit
[candidate@base ~]$

2. SELECTOR TYPES (CRITICAL):
   â€¢ podSelector: Selects pods within the same namespace
   â€¢ namespaceSelector: Selects entire namespaces
   â€¢ Combined: namespaceSelector + podSelector (AND operation)
   â€¢ ipBlock: Selects IP ranges (CIDR blocks)

3. POLICY EVALUATION:
   â€¢ Default: All traffic allowed (no NetworkPolicies)
   â€¢ With NetworkPolicy: Default deny + explicit allow rules
   â€¢ Multiple policies: Union of all allow rules
   â€¢ Precedence: More specific policies take effect

ğŸš€ EXAM SUCCESS STRATEGIES:

1. TIME MANAGEMENT:
   â€¢ This question: 10-15 minutes maximum
   â€¢ Read all policy files first before deciding
   â€¢ Analyze pod and namespace labels carefully
   â€¢ Apply policy and verify with kubectl describe

2. COMMON MISTAKES TO AVOID:
   âŒ Choosing overly permissive policy (netpol1 type)
   âŒ Applying policy that doesn't match existing labels
   âŒ Modifying or deleting existing default-deny policy
   âŒ Not understanding AND vs OR in selectors
   âŒ Forgetting to check policy effectiveness

3. VERIFICATION CHECKLIST:
   âœ… kubectl get ns --show-labels (check namespace labels)
   âœ… kubectl get pods -n NS --show-labels (check pod labels)
   âœ… kubectl get networkpolicies -n NS (check existing policies)
   âœ… kubectl describe networkpolicy NAME -n NS (verify rules)
   âœ… Test connectivity with kubectl exec ... curl

4. ANALYSIS FRAMEWORK:
   â€¢ Step 1: Identify source (frontend) and target (backend) labels
   â€¢ Step 2: Examine each policy's podSelector and ingress rules
   â€¢ Step 3: Choose policy that matches labels without being overly broad
   â€¢ Step 4: Apply and verify policy takes effect

ğŸ“š SERVICES & NETWORKING DOMAIN (20% of CKA):

â€¢ NetworkPolicy Types: Ingress, Egress, Both
â€¢ Selectors: podSelector, namespaceSelector, ipBlock
â€¢ Policy Evaluation: Default allow â†’ Default deny with explicit allows
â€¢ CNI Requirements: Calico, Cilium, Weave (not all CNIs support NetworkPolicies)
â€¢ Use Cases: Micro-segmentation, compliance, security isolation

ğŸ”§ TROUBLESHOOTING TIPS:

Policy not working?
â†’ Check: CNI supports NetworkPolicies, labels match exactly, policy applied to correct namespace

Traffic still blocked?
â†’ Check: Multiple policies (union of rules), default-deny policies, pod readiness

Overly permissive?
â†’ Check: Empty podSelector {} affects all pods, missing label selectors

Labels don't match?
â†’ Check: kubectl get pods --show-labels, case sensitivity, exact matches required

ğŸ’¡ EXAM DAY REMINDERS:

1. Always check existing labels before choosing policy
2. Avoid overly permissive policies (empty selectors)
3. Don't modify existing default-deny policies
4. Test policy effectiveness with kubectl exec curl
5. Remember: namespaceSelector + podSelector = AND operation

ğŸ” DEBUGGING COMMANDS:

â€¢ kubectl get ns --show-labels
â€¢ kubectl get pods -n NAMESPACE --show-labels
â€¢ kubectl get networkpolicies -A
â€¢ kubectl describe networkpolicy NAME -n NAMESPACE
â€¢ kubectl exec -n NS deployment/NAME -- curl IP

ğŸ“‹ NETWORKPOLICY ANALYSIS TEMPLATE:

```yaml
# Policy Analysis Checklist:
# 1. What pods does podSelector target?
# 2. What traffic does policyTypes control?
# 3. What sources do ingress rules allow?
# 4. Do selectors match existing labels?
# 5. Is policy appropriately restrictive?

apiVersion: networking.k8s.io/v1
kind: NetworkPolicy
metadata:
  name: POLICY-NAME
  namespace: TARGET-NAMESPACE
spec:
  podSelector:
    matchLabels:
      app: TARGET-LABEL
  policyTypes:
  - Ingress
  ingress:
  - from:
    - namespaceSelector:
        matchLabels:
          kubernetes.io/metadata.name: SOURCE-NAMESPACE
      podSelector:
        matchLabels:
          app: SOURCE-LABEL
```

ğŸ¯ POLICY SELECTION CRITERIA:

âœ… **GOOD POLICY (netpol2 type)**:
- Specific pod selectors (app=backend)
- Specific source selectors (app=frontend)
- Follows principle of least privilege
- Matches existing pod labels

âŒ **BAD POLICY (netpol1 type)**:
- Empty pod selector (affects all pods)
- Only namespace selector (too broad)
- Overly permissive access
- Violates security best practices

âŒ **IRRELEVANT POLICY (netpol3 type)**:
- Selectors don't match existing labels
- Policy has no effect
- Wastes exam time

2. CONFIGMAP UPDATE METHODS (CRITICAL):
   â€¢ kubectl edit configmap NAME -n NAMESPACE (direct edit)
   â€¢ kubectl apply -f updated-configmap.yaml (file-based)
   â€¢ kubectl patch configmap NAME --patch '...' (patch-based)
   â€¢ kubectl create configmap --dry-run=client -o yaml (generate)

3. DEPLOYMENT UPDATE STRATEGIES:
   â€¢ Rolling Update: Default, zero-downtime updates
   â€¢ Recreate: All pods terminated, then new ones created
   â€¢ Manual Restart: kubectl rollout restart deployment NAME

ğŸš€ EXAM SUCCESS STRATEGIES:

1. TIME MANAGEMENT:
   â€¢ This question: 8-12 minutes maximum
   â€¢ Export ConfigMap first (kubectl get cm NAME -o yaml > file.yaml)
   â€¢ Use sed for simple text replacements (faster than vim)
   â€¢ Always restart deployment after ConfigMap changes

2. COMMON MISTAKES TO AVOID:
   âŒ Forgetting to restart deployment after ConfigMap update
   âŒ Editing ConfigMap directly without backing up
   âŒ Not verifying the change took effect in the pod
   âŒ Incorrect YAML indentation when editing
   âŒ Not testing the actual functionality

3. VERIFICATION CHECKLIST:
   âœ… kubectl get configmap NAME -o yaml (verify ConfigMap updated)
   âœ… kubectl rollout status deployment NAME (verify restart completed)
   âœ… kubectl get pods (verify new pod is running)
   âœ… kubectl exec ... -- cat /path/to/config (verify file in pod)
   âœ… Test actual functionality (curl, etc.)

4. EFFICIENT WORKFLOW:
   â€¢ Step 1: Export ConfigMap to file
   â€¢ Step 2: Edit file (vim or sed)
   â€¢ Step 3: Apply updated ConfigMap
   â€¢ Step 4: Restart deployment
   â€¢ Step 5: Verify and test

ğŸ“š WORKLOADS & SCHEDULING DOMAIN (15% of CKA):

â€¢ ConfigMaps: Configuration data storage and injection
â€¢ Secrets: Sensitive data storage (certificates, passwords)
â€¢ Volume Mounts: File-based configuration injection
â€¢ Environment Variables: Key-value configuration injection
â€¢ Rolling Updates: Zero-downtime configuration updates

ğŸ”§ TROUBLESHOOTING TIPS:

ConfigMap changes not applied?
â†’ Check: Deployment restarted, pod recreated, volume mount correct

Pod failing to start after config change?
â†’ Check: Configuration syntax, file paths, permissions

TLS/SSL not working?
â†’ Check: Certificate paths, protocol versions, cipher suites

Configuration file not found in pod?
â†’ Check: Volume mount path, subPath specification, ConfigMap key name

ğŸ’¡ EXAM DAY REMINDERS:

1. Always backup ConfigMap before editing (export to file)
2. Restart deployment after ConfigMap changes (not automatic)
3. Use kubectl rollout status to verify restart completion
4. Test actual functionality, not just resource status
5. subPath is required when mounting single files from ConfigMap

ğŸ” DEBUGGING COMMANDS:

â€¢ kubectl get configmap NAME -o yaml
â€¢ kubectl describe configmap NAME
â€¢ kubectl exec POD -- cat /path/to/config/file
â€¢ kubectl rollout history deployment NAME
â€¢ kubectl logs deployment/NAME

ğŸ“‹ CONFIGMAP UPDATE WORKFLOW:

```bash

kubectl get configmap NAME -n NAMESPACE -o yaml > config.yaml

# 2. Edit configuration (vim or sed)
vim config.yaml
# OR
sed -i 's/old-value/new-value/' config.yaml

# 3. Apply updated ConfigMap
kubectl apply -f config.yaml

# 4. Restart deployment
kubectl rollout restart deployment NAME -n NAMESPACE

# 5. Verify rollout
kubectl rollout status deployment NAME -n NAMESPACE

# 6. Test functionality

```

âœ… **ENTIRE CONFIGMAP AS ENV**:

2. VOLUME BINDING MODES (CRITICAL):
   â€¢ Immediate: PV created immediately when PVC is created
   â€¢ WaitForFirstConsumer: PV created when first pod using PVC is scheduled
   â€¢ WaitForFirstConsumer is often preferred for node-local storage

3. DEFAULT STORAGECLASS:
   â€¢ Only one StorageClass can be default at a time
   â€¢ Annotation: storageclass.kubernetes.io/is-default-class: "true"
   â€¢ Used when PVC doesn't specify storageClassName

ğŸš€ EXAM SUCCESS STRATEGIES:

1. TIME MANAGEMENT:
   â€¢ This question: 5-8 minutes maximum
   â€¢ Simple YAML creation and application
   â€¢ Verify default status with kubectl get storageclass
   â€¢ Test with a simple PVC if time permits

2. COMMON MISTAKES TO AVOID:
   âŒ Wrong provisioner name (must match exactly)
   âŒ Incorrect volumeBindingMode (question specifies WaitForFirstConsumer)
   âŒ Missing default annotation
   âŒ Modifying existing resources (explicitly forbidden)
   âŒ Not verifying the StorageClass is actually default

3. VERIFICATION CHECKLIST:
   âœ… kubectl get storageclass (check for "(default)" indicator)
   âœ… kubectl describe storageclass NAME (verify all fields)
   âœ… kubectl get storageclass NAME -o yaml (check annotations)
   âœ… Create test PVC without storageClassName (should use default)

4. YAML TEMPLATE:
```yaml
apiVersion: storage.k8s.io/v1
kind: StorageClass
metadata:
  name: REQUIRED-NAME
  annotations:
    storageclass.kubernetes.io/is-default-class: "true"
provisioner: EXACT-PROVISIONER-NAME
volumeBindingMode: WaitForFirstConsumer
reclaimPolicy: Delete
```

ğŸ“š STORAGE DOMAIN (10% of CKA):

â€¢ StorageClass: Defines storage provisioning policies
â€¢ Dynamic Provisioning: Automatic PV creation based on PVC requests
â€¢ Provisioners: CSI drivers, cloud providers, local storage
â€¢ Volume Binding: Immediate vs WaitForFirstConsumer
â€¢ Reclaim Policies: Delete, Retain, Recycle

ğŸ”§ TROUBLESHOOTING TIPS:

StorageClass not working?
â†’ Check: Provisioner exists, correct provisioner name, RBAC permissions

PVC stuck in Pending?
â†’ Check: StorageClass exists, provisioner running, node resources

Default StorageClass not used?
â†’ Check: Only one default exists, annotation correct, PVC has no storageClassName

Volume binding issues?
â†’ Check: VolumeBindingMode, node affinity, pod scheduling constraints

ğŸ’¡ EXAM DAY REMINDERS:

1. Read question carefully for exact provisioner name
2. VolumeBindingMode is often specified in question requirements
3. Only one StorageClass can be default at a time
4. Don't modify existing resources unless explicitly asked

ğŸ” DEBUGGING COMMANDS:

ğŸ“‹ STORAGECLASS FIELDS REFERENCE:

**Required Fields:**
- apiVersion: storage.k8s.io/v1
- kind: StorageClass
- metadata.name: StorageClass name

**Important Optional Fields:**

- âœ… Simple, immediate provisioning

- âŒ Pod scheduling may fail

**WaitForFirstConsumer:**
- âœ… Optimal node placement

- âœ… Prevents scheduling conflicts

Create a new HorizontalPodAutoscaler (HPA) named nginx-server in the autoscale namespace. This HPA must target the existing Deployment named nginx-server in the autoscale namespace.

- Worker node: ec2-54-144-18-63.compute-1.amazonaws.com (54.144.18.63, Private: 172.31.80.11)

kubectl get ns autoscale  # namespace exists
kubectl get deployment -n autoscale nginx-server  # deployment exists with resource limits

[ubuntu@ec2-34-201-252-187.compute-1.amazonaws.com ~]$

2. HPA VERSIONS (CRITICAL):
   â€¢ autoscaling/v1: Basic CPU-based scaling only
   â€¢ autoscaling/v2: Advanced metrics, behavior, multiple metrics
   â€¢ autoscaling/v2beta2: Deprecated, use v2

3. SCALING METRICS:
   â€¢ Resource: CPU, Memory (percentage of requests)
   â€¢ Pods: Custom metrics per pod
   â€¢ Object: Custom metrics from Kubernetes objects
   â€¢ External: External metrics (Prometheus, etc.)

ğŸš€ EXAM SUCCESS STRATEGIES:

1. TIME MANAGEMENT:
   â€¢ This question: 8-12 minutes maximum
   â€¢ Use kubectl autoscale for basic HPA creation (fastest)
   â€¢ Use YAML for advanced configuration (behavior)
   â€¢ Always verify metrics-server is working first

2. COMMON MISTAKES TO AVOID:
   âŒ Missing resource requests in deployment (HPA won't work)
   âŒ Wrong API version (use autoscaling/v2 for behavior)
   âŒ Incorrect target reference (must match deployment name)
   âŒ Not verifying metrics-server is running
   âŒ Forgetting to specify namespace

3. VERIFICATION CHECKLIST:
   âœ… kubectl top nodes (verify metrics-server working)
   âœ… kubectl get hpa -n NAMESPACE (check HPA status)
   âœ… kubectl describe hpa NAME -n NAMESPACE (verify configuration)
   âœ… kubectl get deployment -n NAMESPACE (check resource requests)
   âœ… Generate load to test scaling (if time permits)

4. QUICK CREATION WORKFLOW:
   â€¢ Step 1: kubectl autoscale deployment NAME --cpu-percent=X --min=Y --max=Z
   â€¢ Step 2: kubectl apply -f hpa.yaml (for behavior configuration)
   â€¢ Step 3: kubectl get hpa (verify creation)
   â€¢ Step 4: kubectl describe hpa (verify all settings)

ğŸ“š WORKLOADS & SCHEDULING DOMAIN (15% of CKA):

â€¢ HPA: Horizontal scaling based on metrics
â€¢ VPA: Vertical scaling (resource requests/limits)
â€¢ Resource Requests/Limits: Required for HPA functionality
â€¢ Metrics Server: Provides resource metrics API
â€¢ Custom Metrics: Prometheus, external metrics adapters

ğŸ”§ TROUBLESHOOTING TIPS:

HPA not working?
â†’ Check: Metrics-server running, resource requests defined, correct target reference

Metrics showing <unknown>?
â†’ Check: Metrics-server pods, resource requests in deployment, wait for metrics collection

HPA not scaling?
â†’ Check: CPU threshold reached, stabilization windows, min/max replica limits

Scaling too aggressive?
â†’ Check: Behavior configuration, stabilization windows, scaling policies

ğŸ’¡ EXAM DAY REMINDERS:

1. Verify metrics-server is running before creating HPA
2. Deployment MUST have resource requests for HPA to work
3. Use kubectl autoscale for quick creation, YAML for advanced features
4. Behavior configuration requires autoscaling/v2 API version
5. Test with kubectl top pods to see current resource usage

ğŸ” DEBUGGING COMMANDS:

â€¢ kubectl top nodes (verify metrics-server)
â€¢ kubectl top pods -n NAMESPACE (check pod resource usage)
â€¢ kubectl get hpa -n NAMESPACE (check HPA status)
â€¢ kubectl describe hpa NAME -n NAMESPACE (detailed configuration)
â€¢ kubectl get events -n NAMESPACE (check scaling events)

ğŸ“‹ HPA YAML TEMPLATE:

```yaml
apiVersion: autoscaling/v2
kind: HorizontalPodAutoscaler
metadata:
  name: HPA-NAME
  namespace: NAMESPACE
spec:
  scaleTargetRef:
    apiVersion: apps/v1
    kind: Deployment
    name: DEPLOYMENT-NAME
  minReplicas: MIN-REPLICAS
  maxReplicas: MAX-REPLICAS
  metrics:
  - type: Resource
    resource:
      name: cpu
      target:
        type: Utilization
        averageUtilization: TARGET-PERCENTAGE
  behavior:
    scaleDown:
      stabilizationWindowSeconds: SECONDS
    scaleUp:
      stabilizationWindowSeconds: SECONDS
```

ğŸ¯ KUBECTL AUTOSCALE SYNTAX:

```bash
kubectl autoscale deployment DEPLOYMENT-NAME \
  --cpu-percent=TARGET-PERCENTAGE \
  --min=MIN-REPLICAS \
  --max=MAX-REPLICAS \
  -n NAMESPACE
```

ğŸ”§ SCALING CALCULATION:

**Formula**: `desiredReplicas = ceil(currentReplicas * currentMetric / targetMetric)`

**Example**:
- Current replicas: 1
- Current CPU: 80%
- Target CPU: 50%
- Desired replicas: ceil(1 * 80/50) = ceil(1.6) = 2

ğŸ¯ BEHAVIOR CONFIGURATION:

**Scale Up Policies**:
- Type: Pods (absolute number)
- Type: Percent (percentage increase)
- Period: Time window for policy

**Scale Down Policies**:
- stabilizationWindowSeconds: Prevents flapping
- selectPolicy: Max, Min, Disabled
- Policies: Same as scale up

**Common Stabilization Windows**:
- Scale Up: 0-60 seconds (default: 0)
- Scale Down: 60-300 seconds (default: 300)

   âŒ Modifying wrong deployment or other deployments
   âŒ Not verifying the rollout completed

3. VERIFICATION CHECKLIST:
   âœ… kubectl get priorityclass --sort-by=.value (check priority order)
   âœ… kubectl get deployment NAME -o yaml | grep priority (verify deployment)
   âœ… kubectl describe pod POD-NAME | grep Priority (verify pod priority)
   âœ… kubectl rollout status deployment NAME (verify rollout)

4. EFFICIENT WORKFLOW:
   â€¢ Step 1: kubectl get priorityclass --sort-by=.value
   â€¢ Step 2: Identify highest user-defined value
   â€¢ Step 3: Create PriorityClass with value - 1
   â€¢ Step 4: kubectl patch deployment to add priorityClassName
   â€¢ Step 5: Verify rollout and pod priority

ğŸ“š WORKLOADS & SCHEDULING DOMAIN (15% of CKA):

â€¢ PriorityClass: Defines scheduling priority for pods
â€¢ Pod Priority: Numeric value determining scheduling order
â€¢ Preemption: Higher priority pods can evict lower priority
â€¢ Scheduler: Uses priority for queue ordering and resource allocation
â€¢ QoS Classes: BestEffort, Burstable, Guaranteed (separate from priority)

ğŸ”§ TROUBLESHOOTING TIPS:

PriorityClass not working?
â†’ Check: Correct value range, valid YAML syntax, applied successfully

Pod not getting priority?
â†’ Check: priorityClassName in deployment spec, pod recreated after update

Deployment not updating?
â†’ Check: Correct namespace, deployment name, rollout status

Priority not showing in pod?
â†’ Check: Pod is new (created after deployment update), correct pod name

ğŸ’¡ EXAM DAY REMINDERS:

1. Always check existing PriorityClasses first with --sort-by=.value
2. Calculate "one less" correctly (subtract 1 from highest user-defined)
3. Use kubectl patch for quick deployment updates
4. Verify pod priority with kubectl describe pod
5. Don't modify system PriorityClasses or other deployments

ğŸ” DEBUGGING COMMANDS:

â€¢ kubectl get priorityclass --sort-by=.value
â€¢ kubectl describe priorityclass NAME
â€¢ kubectl get deployment NAME -o yaml | grep priority
â€¢ kubectl describe pod POD-NAME | grep -E 'Priority|QoS'
â€¢ kubectl rollout status deployment NAME

ğŸ“‹ PRIORITYCLASS YAML TEMPLATE:

```yaml
apiVersion: scheduling.k8s.io/v1
kind: PriorityClass
metadata:
  name: PRIORITY-CLASS-NAME
value: PRIORITY-VALUE
globalDefault: false
description: 'Description of priority class'
```

ğŸ¯ KUBECTL PATCH SYNTAX:

```bash
kubectl patch deployment DEPLOYMENT-NAME -n NAMESPACE \
  -p '{"spec":{"template":{"spec":{"priorityClassName":"PRIORITY-CLASS-NAME"}}}}'
```

ğŸ”§ PRIORITY VALUE GUIDELINES:

**System Reserved**: 2000000000 and above
- system-node-critical: 2000001000
- system-cluster-critical: 2000000000

**User Range**: 0 to 1999999999
- High priority: 1000000000+
- Medium priority: 100000000+
- Low priority: 1000000+
- Default: 0

**Calculation Example**:
- Existing max-priority: 1000000000
- Required high-priority: 999999999 (1000000000 - 1)

ğŸ¯ PREEMPTION BEHAVIOR:

**When Resources Scarce**:
1. Higher priority pod submitted
2. No available resources on any node
3. Scheduler identifies lower priority pods to evict
4. Lower priority pods terminated
5. Higher priority pod scheduled

**Preemption Policy**:
- PreemptLowerPriority (default): Can preempt lower priority
- Never: Cannot preempt any pods

**Limits (Enforcement)**:

- Consider application behavior
